drcongo.notes: Belgian colony before 1960. RHD vehicles are common, especially in the southeast.

japan.notes: LHT enacted in law in 1924. One of the few non-British-colony countries to use LHT. Okinawa was RHT from 24 June 1945 to 30 July 1978.

gambia.notes: British colony until 1965. Switched to RHT on 1 October 1965 being surrounded by the former French colony of Senegal.

turksandcaicosislands.notes: Most passenger vehicles are LHD due to imports from the United Sates, which had RHT.

philippines.notes: Was LHT during the Spanish and American colonial periods. Switched to RHT after the Battle of Manila in 1945. Philippine National Railways switched to RHT in 2010.

usvirginislands.notes: U.S. Virgin Islands, like much of the Caribbean, is LHT and is the only American jurisdiction that still has LHT, because the islands drove on the left when the US purchased the former Danish West Indies in the 1917 Treaty of the Danish West Indies. Most passenger vehicles are LHD due to them being imported from the American mainland.

mauritius.notes: This island nation was a British colony before 1968.

mali.notes: Part of French West Africa before 1960.

vietnam.notes: French colony until 1954. The Long Bien Bridge uses LHT.

australia.notes: British colonies before 1901. Includes Australian external territories.

laos.notes: French protectorate until 1953. The Thai-Lao Friendship Bridge is LHT in connection to Thailand.

unitedkingdom.notes: An island nation with a land border with the Republic of Ireland, which is also LHT. Also LHT are the Crown dependencies of the Isle of Man, and the British Overseas Territories of Anguilla, Ascension Island, Bermuda, Montserrat, Saint Helena, and Tristan da Cunha.

newzealand.notes: These Pacific islands, including territories Niue and Cook Islands, were former British colonies.

turkey.notes: Except Metrobus, which is usually LHT.

ukraine.notes: Western parts of the country had LHT under Austro-Hungarian Empire

austria.notes: Originally LHT, like most of Austria-Hungary, but switched sides after the annexation of Austria by Nazi Germany.

hungary.notes: Originally LHT, like most of Austria-Hungary, but switched sides during the Second World War.

kenya.notes: Part of the British East Africa Protectorate before 1963.

greece.notes: Originally LHT (albeit in an unofficial manner) since independence, the establishment of the traffic code switched traffic officially to RHT traffic in 1926.

palau.notes: Most passenger vehicles are RHD due to them being imported from Australia and Japan.

vanuatu.notes: Co-administered under France and the United Kingdom until 1980.

cyprus.notes: Under UK administration before 1960. Island nation. De facto divided between the Republic of Cyprus, the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus, the UN buffer zone and the British base areas of Akrotiri and Dhekelia. All are LHT.

britishcolumbia.notes: Interior changed 15 July 1920, Vancouver and the coastal area 1 January 1922

papuanewguinea.notes: After Australia occupied German New Guinea during World War I, it switched to LHT.

rwanda.notes: Belgian colony before 1962. Considering switching to LHT.

guernsey.notes: Was RHT from 1940 to 1945 due to the German occupation.

bosniaandherzegovina.notes: Switched sides after the collapse of Austria-Hungary.

bahrain.notes: Former British protectorate. Switched to the same side as its neighbours. An island nation, linked by road to the Arabian mainland since 1986.

southkorea.notes: Was LHT during the period of Japanese rule. Switched to RHT after the Surrender of Japan.

ghana.notes: British colony until 1957. Ghana switched to RHT in 1974, a Twi language slogan was \"Nifa, Nifa Enan\" or \"Right, Right, Fourth\". Ghana has also banned RHD vehicles - it prohibited new registrations of RHD vehicles after 1 August 1974, three days before the traffic change.

somalia.notes: The former British Somaliland had LHT until it formed a union with the former Italian Somaliland which had RHT.

jamaica.notes: British colony before 1962. Caribbean island. Most passenger vehicles are RDH, tractor trailers and other heavy-duty trucks are mostly LHD due to being imported from the United States.

togo.notes: Part of French West Africa until 1960.

thailand.notes: One of the few non-British-colony LHT countries. Shares a long land border with RHT Myanmar, Laos and Cambodia.

france.notes: Includes French Polynesia, New Caledonia, Saint Pierre and Miquelon, Wallis and Futuna, French Guiana, R\u00E9union, Saint Barth\u00E9lemy, the Collectivity of Saint Martin, Guadeloupe, and Mayotte.

serbia.notes: (as part of Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes), Vojvodina was LHT while part of Austria-Hungary.

solomonislands.notes: This island nation was a British protectorate before 1975.

senegal.notes: Part of French West Africa before 1960.

britishvirginislands.notes: Most passenger vehicles are LHD due to imports from the United States, which is RHT.

namibia.notes: When South Africa occupied German South West Africa in the First World War, it switched to LHT. South West Africa was administered by South Africa 1920\u20131990.

taiwan.notes: Was LHT during the period of Japanese rule. The government of the Republic of China changed Taiwan to RHT in 1946 along with the rest of China.

burkinafaso.notes: Part of French West Africa before 1958.

maldives.notes: This island nation was a British colony before 1965.

guyana.notes: British colony until 1966. One of the only two countries in continental America which are in LHT, the other being Suriname.

lesotho.notes: British protectorate from 1885 to 1966. Enclave of LHT South Africa.

saintkittsandnevis.notes: This Caribbean island nation was a British colony before 1983.

denmark.notes: Includes the Faroe Islands and Greenland.

sierraleone.notes: British colony until 1961. Switched to RHT being surrounded by neighbouring former French colonies. Furthermore, it banned the importation of RHD vehicles in 2013.

jersey.notes: Was RHT from 1940 to 1945 due to the German occupation.

belize.notes: British colony before 1981. Switched to same side as neighbours.

nauru.notes: This island nation was administered by Australia until 1968.

slovenia.notes: (as part of Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes), officially LHT from 1915 as part of Austria-Hungary.

zimbabwe.notes: British colony before 1965 (de facto) or 1980 (de jure).

ireland.notes: Part of the United Kingdom before 1922. An island nation with a land border with the United Kingdom, which is also LHT.

srilanka.notes: Part of British Ceylon from 1815 to 1948.

poland.notes: South-eastern Poland (former Austrian Partition) was LHT until the 1920s.

eswatini.notes: British protectorate until 1968. Continues to drive on the same side as neighbouring countries.

russia.notes: In the Russian Far East, RHD vehicles are common due to the import of used cars from nearby Japan. The railway between Moscow and Ryazan, the Sormovskaya line in Nizhny Novgorod Metro and the Moskva River cable car use LHT.

sweden.notes: The day of the switch was known as Dagen H. Most passenger vehicles were already LHD.

saintlucia.notes: These Caribbean island nations were British colonies before 1979.

pitcairnislands.notes: There is no official vehicle registration system.

seychelles.notes: This island nation was a British colony until 1976.

indonesia.notes: Roads and railways were built by the Dutch, with LHT for roads to conform to British and Japanese standards and RHT for railways to conform with Dutch standards. Urban railways also use RHT. Did not change sides, unlike the Netherlands, in 1906.

gibraltar.notes: Gibraltar is RHT because of its land border with Spain.

guinea-bissau.notes: Portuguese colony until 1974. Drives on the same side as its neighbours.

mauritania.notes: Part of French West Africa before 1960. Mining roads between Fder\u00EEck and Zou\u00E9rat are LHT.

spain.notes: Up to the 1920s Barcelona was RHT, and Madrid was LHT until 1924. The Madrid Metro still uses LHT.

mozambique.notes: Portuguese colony until 1975. Drives on the same side as its neighbours.

portugal.notes: Colonies Goa, Macau and Mozambique, which had land borders with LHT countries, did not switch and continue to drive on the left. The Porto Metro uses RHT.

benin.notes: Part of French West Africa before 1960.

nigeria.notes: British colony until 1960. Switched to RHT due to being surrounded by RHT former French colonies.

sudan.notes: Formerly Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, it switched sides 17 years later to match neighbours.

fiji.notes: The island nation was a British colony before 1970.

antiguaandbarbuda.notes: This Caribbean island was a British colony until 1958.

singapore.notes: This island nation was a British colony until 1963. It was also part of Malaysia until 1965.

samoa.notes: When New Zealand occupied German Samoa during the first World War, switched to LHT for economic reasons: to allow cheaper importation of cars from Australia, New Zealand and Japan.

tunisia.notes: RHT was enforced in the French protectorate of Tunisia from 1881 to 1956.

bahamas.notes: British colony before 1973. Caribbean island. Most passenger vehicles are LHD due to them being imported from the United States.

ivorycoast.notes: Part of French West Africa before 1960.

uganda.notes: Part of British Uganda Protectorate from 1894 until 1962.

uruguay.notes: Became LHT in 1918, but as in some other countries in South America, changed to RHT in 1945. A speed limit of 30 km/h (19 mph) was observed until 30 September for safety.

niger.notes: Part of French West Africa before 1958.

kyrgyzstan.notes: In 2012, over 20,000 cheap used RHD cars were imported from Japan.

falklandislands.notes: Briefly switched to RHT during the Falklands War.

georgia.notes: About 40% of vehicles in Georgia are RHD due to the low cost of used cars imported from Japan.

yemen.notes: South Yemen, formerly the British colony of Aden, changed to RHT in 1977. A series of postage stamps commemorating the event was issued. At that time, North Yemen was already RHT.

argentina.notes: The anniversary on 10 June is still observed each year as D\u00EDa de la Seguridad Vial (road safety day).

czechrepublic.notes: Switched during the German occupation of Czechoslovakia.

burundi.notes: Belgian colony before 1962. Considering switching to LHT.

slovakia.notes: Switched during the German occupation of Czechoslovakia.

northkorea.notes: Was LHT during the period of Japanese rule. Switched to RHT after the Surrender of Japan.

netherlands.notes: Includes Aruba, Cura\u00E7ao, and Sint Maarten.

caymanislands.notes: Most passenger vehicles are LHD due to imports from the United States, which has RHT.

croatia.notes: Was then part of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes.

nepal.notes: Shares open land border with LHT India.

morocco.notes: Under French and Spanish protection until 1956.

suriname.notes: Dutch colony until 1975. One of the only two countries in continental America which are in LHT, the other being Guyana. Did not switch sides, unlike the Netherlands itself.

romania.notes: Regions of Romania (Transylvania, Bukovina, parts of the Banat, Cri\u0219ana and Maramure\u0219) that were part of Austria-Hungary were LHT until 1919.

easttimor.notes: Portuguese colony until 1975. Switched to RHT with Portugal in 1928; under the Indonesian annexation, it was switched back to LHT in 1976. Its LHT status remains to this day.

iceland.notes: Changed from LHT on H-dagurinn. Most passenger cars were already LHD.

myanmar.notes: British colony until 1948. Switched to RHT under the orders of Ne Win. Theories emerge on the reasoning behind this switch; one claimed that he met an astrologer that recommends him to switch the country's traffic to the right in order to make the nation prosper, while another claimed that international visits cause him to notice that most countries are RHT and so decided to convert the country's handedness of traffic in order to connect Myanmar\u2019s roads with other countries' roads in the future.

macau.notes: Macau was under Portuguese rule until 1999, when the dependent territory was transferred to China.

tuvalu.notes: Formerly a British colony. Became independent in 1978.

qatar.notes: Former British protectorate. Switched to same side as neighbours.

tonga.notes: British protectorate before 1970. Polynesian island nation.

barbados.notes: This Atlantic island state was a British colony before 1966.

hongkong.notes: Hong Kong was a British colony from 1841 to 1941 and from 1945 to 1997, when the dependent territory was transferred to China.
